awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Genus one curves: rational points and arithmetic statistics
awd_abstract_narration:
A central topic in number theory is the study of diophantine equations, that is, the search for integer solutions to polynomial equations with integer coefficients. It has proved highly fruitful to view such equations not only from an algebraic perspective but also from a geometric one; the field of arithmetic geometry provides a language to do so. Elliptic curves (and the closely related genus one curves) are a fascinating class of diophantine equations. The proposed research bears on basic questions of solvability of algebraic equations that define genus one curves, as well as other arithmetic-geometric aspects of such equations. The PI plans to organize a collaborative workshop with specialists from three different areas of number theory that impact the proposed research; and a lecture series on recent developments in number theory which will expose faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates to new and exciting mathematics in this area. 

The basic objects of study of the proposed research are genus one curves and their rational points.The PI will investigate them from three distinct perspectives: proving, in joint work with A. Wiles, the existence of solvable points on genus one curves defined over the rationals; analyzing the structure of local points on supersingular elliptic curves over Z_p extensions; and studying the arithmetic statistics of the existence of points on quadratic twists of elliptic curves viewed as genus one curves.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The aim of the proposed projects was to extend our understanding of genus one curves and elliptic curves in various ways.

One question is to understand when a genus one curve defined over the rationals acquires a rational point. We ask this question about general genus one curves defined over the rational numbers Q and our desired answer would be to conclude that all such curves acquire a point over some radical extension of Q.

The completion of our work towards this result requires the extension of our understanding of local points on supersingular elliptic curves. In our efforts to explore this structure we have made some progress by proving that the even/odd local points of elliptic curves at supersingular primes have corank 2 and cotorsion intersection when viewed in the relevant cohomology group, in the case of certain Z_p extensions of any quadratic extension of Q_p. In simpler terms we prove that in this case the local points of the elliptic curve break out in a way that may allow us to see that the complex multiplication points (i.e., the only global points that we can construct) may be sufficient to prove the desired result for genus one curves. If one could see that this local result is false then our strategy to our original aim would have no chance of success. This work is fine enough that it allows us to test conjectures about the further splitting of supersingular points.

Another direction of this work was to explore when certain genus one curves, defined as twists of elliptic curves over Q (viewed as a genus one curves) with respect to a quadratic extension and a rational point of the elliptic curve, acquire rational points. We first ask the question locally and then globally. While the local answer is satisfactory in that we can determine conditions on the quadratic extension that guarantee the existence of a (local) rational point. The global result is not satisfactory because the condition that we find cannot be verified before the quadratic extension is selected and it is difficult (not always possible) to verify even afterwards. As a result we changed our approach to a statistical one. We want to look at quadratic fields with discriminants within a certain range and determine what proportion give rise to twists with local points and then ask the corresponding statistical global question. This gives rise to interesting results. The set of twists with guaranteed local points at every prime is an infinite set whose density we now understand. We then proceed to show that global points are also guaranteed to exist for an infinite subset of the quadratic extensions where we can guarantee the existence of local points everywhere. When we are able to guarantee the existence of global rational points, we use earlier work by Kramer to deduce that if the elliptic curve that we started with had analytic rank 0, then under certain conditions the usual quadratic twist of the elliptic curve with respect to the quadratic extension that we have chosen, has analytic rank at least two (even if we only construct one point). We are currently working on understanding the density of such quadratic extensions. This will give interesting lower bounds on the number of quadratic twists with analytic ranks greater than one.

 

In addition to supporting the above work this grant was used to support a vertically integrated public lecture series. We had several speakers lecture on current hot topics in number theory. In each case there was a graduate student who gave a lecture to the graduate and undergraduate students following the guidance of the speaker, with the aim of preparing this audience for the more advance topic of the colloquium.  The last of these colloquia was scheduled for March 2020 and got cancelled due to the pandemic. The lecture series was an energizing activity at all levels and I will try to continue it.
